itineraries.title: The Don Quixote Route: A Road Trip Through Castilla-La Mancha's Windmills & Plains

visits.text: Discover the magnificent Toledo Cathedral, one of the most impressive in Spain with its blend of Gothic, Mudéjar and Renaissance styles. Don't miss the Chapel of the Kings, the famous gold Monstrance, the magnificent paintings in the Sacristy, and the Choir. An essential visit in the city of the three cultures.

Explore the imposing Alcázar of Toledo, a fortress dominating the city from above. Climb to one of its towers to enjoy a spectacular panoramic view of Toledo from the sky. It currently houses the Castilla-La Mancha Library and the Army Museum.

Visit the Santa Cruz Museum, a complex formed by the former Hospital of Santa Cruz and the Convent of Santa Fe. The Hospital building features an impressive courtyard, a marble staircase by Covarrubias, and enormous interior arches well worth contemplating.

Admire El Greco's masterpiece, 'The Burial of the Count of Orgaz', in the Church of Santo Tomé. This 16th-century painting is one of the jewels of Spanish art and masterfully represents the mysticism of the era with its composition divided between the earthly and celestial worlds.

activities.text: Wander through Toledo's Jewish Quarter, one of the most charming neighborhoods in the city. Visit the Synagogue of El Tránsito, home to the Sephardic Museum, and the Santa María la Blanca Synagogue with its filigree work and capitals that amaze everyone. Discover the legacy of Jewish culture in Spain.

Stroll through the convent district, where calm and silence reign. In some convents you can buy sweets handcrafted by the nuns. Discover the elevated passageways that the congregations used to move from one building to another unseen.

Visit the Mosque of Cristo de la Luz, the Puerta del Sol, and the Puerta de Bisagra. At sunset, take a taxi to the Parador de Toledo to enjoy superb panoramic views of the city during sunset—the best reward after a day of sightseeing.

visits.text: Behold the famous windmills of Consuegra, the giants of the ingenious gentleman of La Mancha perched on Calderico Hill. Of the thirteen original windmills, twelve have been restored, each with its own name. Visit the interior of the Bolero windmill to understand its workings and layout as a dwelling.

Explore Consuegra Castle, whose origins date back to the era of the Caliphate of Córdoba. It was the headquarters of the Order of Saint John and after its destruction by Napoleonic troops was partially restored. Visit its gallery, cisterns, towers, archive hall, and chapter house.

Discover the Plaza de España with its 1670 Town Hall, where the arch and clock tower stand out. In the same square you'll find the Municipal Museum with archaeological remains from the Neolithic period to the late 19th century.

activities.text: Visit the Church of Cristo de la Veracruz, whose construction began in 1550, with a longitudinal structure and Latin cross plan in Castilian-Mudéjar style. Also stroll by the Prioral Palace and the Casa de la Tercia, the former house of the Order of Saint John.

visits.text: Visit the Corral de Comedias of Almagro, the only complete and intact Golden Age theater in the world. This rectangular building with two floors of galleries was where masters like Lope de Vega, Mateo Alemán, and Tirso de Molina staged their works. Since 1977, it has been the home of the International Festival of Classical Theater.

Stroll through Almagro's Plaza Mayor with its arcades, glazed galleries, and the equestrian statue of Don Diego de Almagro, conqueror of Peru and Captain General of the Kingdom of Chile. The uniformity of the three-story architectural ensemble is impressive.

Explore the Maestral Palace, commissioned by the Order of Calatrava in the 13th century atop a small Arab castle. It was the Mother House of this powerful Order and now houses the National Theater Museum. Its Mudéjar courtyard with horseshoe arches is extraordinary.

Discover the 16th-century Fugger Warehouse, built as a warehouse and office by Emperor Charles V's bankers. The two-story courtyard with semicircular arches and the conventual staircase decorated with egg-and-dart, arrows, and sea wave motifs are magnificent.

activities.text: Visit the Church of San Agustín, an 18th-century Baroque building with impressive frescoes depicting the life of Saint Augustine. The dome over the crossing is a true masterpiece of lacework, leaving practically no space empty of painting.

Explore the Palace of the Counts of Valdeparaíso, a 17th-century Baroque building, and the Palace of the Marquises of Torremegía from the 15th-17th centuries. Don't miss the 16th-century Hermitage of San Blas, rebuilt by the Fuggers, and the Monastery of the Concepción Bernarda.

visits.text: Admire the windmills of Campo de Criptana, the very ones that inspired Cervantes in his famous novel. Of the 34 original windmills, 10 remain, and three of them preserve their original 16th-century machinery and workings. An authentic Quixotic treasure on the Sierra de los Molinos.

Visit the cave-house of the shepherdess Marcela, which preserves its original structure with intact walls. Discover the different rooms: bedrooms, storage, pantry, and the central room with fireplace. A unique way of life carved into the rock of La Mancha.

Explore the Sara Montiel Museum in the Culebro Windmill, dedicated to the life of this actress, singer, and film producer born in Campo de Criptana. See photographs, dresses, and even her grand piano while learning interesting facts about her artistic career.

activities.text: Wander through the Albaicín neighborhood of Campo de Criptana with its narrow, cobbled, and steep streets, its houses with Arab tiles and walls painted white and indigo blue. The panoramic views of the Sierra de los Molinos from this neighborhood are superb.

Visit the 16th-century Royal Granary, the former headquarters of the agricultural bank where loans were made in kind to farmers. It now houses the Archaeological Museum of Campo de Criptana. Don't miss the Convent Church and the Hermitage of the Veracruz from 1573.

visits.text: Contemplate the iconic Hanging Houses of Cuenca, symbol of the city with their large cantilevered balconies over the Huécar River gorge. Inside you'll find the Museum of Spanish Abstract Art. Cross the San Pablo Bridge for the best panoramic view, both by day and by night.

Visit the Cathedral of Santa María and San Julián of Cuenca, predominantly Gothic but with Romanesque and Neo-Gothic elements. Its main façade faces the Plaza Mayor and its interior houses artistic treasures of great value. One of the most unique cathedrals in Spain.

Discover the skyscrapers of Cuenca, a group of 30 buildings that have 4-5 floors on one side and, facing the Huécar Gorge, rise to 8-10 floors on the other. A singular and striking architectural ensemble unique to Spain.

Walk along Alfonso VIII Street and descend through Las Angustias until you find the Hermitage of Our Lady of the Sorrows. Wander through the historic center declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO and discover the castle and Calle de los Tintes along the Huécar River.

activities.text: Visit the Enchanted City, a spectacular site with rock formations sculpted over thousands of years by wind, water, and ice. A 20-meter monolith, the Roman Bridge, and the face of a man are some of the 13 figures along the trail. Nearby is the Devil's Window viewpoint with views of the Júcar River canyon.

Discover the source of the Cuervo River via a trail through willows and hazel trees leading to two breathtaking waterfalls, especially impressive during rainy months. Thirty minutes away, the source of the Júcar River in Tragacete offers a 20-meter waterfall and an old mill.

seo.h1_title: The Don Quixote Route: A Road Trip Through Castilla-La Mancha's Windmills & Plains
seo.intro_paragraph: Step into the pages of literature on this unforgettable 5-day adventure through Castilla-La Mancha, the land that inspired Cervantes' immortal knight. From the imperial grandeur of Toledo to the iconic windmills of La Mancha and the gravity-defying Hanging Houses of Cuenca, this itinerary weaves together UNESCO World Heritage Sites, medieval castles, and timeless landscapes that have fired imaginations for centuries.
seo.seo_hook: Where windmills become giants and every hilltop tells a tale—discover the real La Mancha that sparked the world's first modern novel.
featured_list: Toledo: The City of Three Cultures with El Greco's masterpieces
Iconic windmills of Consuegra and Campo de Criptana
Almagro's Golden Age theater, the only one intact in the world
Cuenca's dramatic Hanging Houses perched over the gorge
The Enchanted City's surreal rock formations

places_taglines.ES::toledo: Imperial city where three cultures forged Spain's soul
places_taglines.ES::consuegra: Where Don Quixote's giants stand guard over La Mancha
places_taglines.ES::almagro: Golden Age theater capital frozen in time
places_taglines.ES::campo-de-criptana: The windmills that inspired Cervantes' immortal tale
places_taglines.ES::cuenca: Hanging Houses and vertiginous beauty carved in stone

itineraries.title: Costa Brava & Beyond: A Catalan Road Trip of Modernism, Coves & Bohemian Towns
itineraries.notes: Des chefs‑d’œuvre de Gaudí aux calanques turquoise, une échappée méditerranéenne pleine de caractère.

visits.text: Sagrada Família — unfinished basilica, stone forest and flamboyant stained glass windows.
Gothic Quarter — cathedral, small squares and medieval alleys.
Passeig de Gràcia — modernist facades, Casa Batlló and Casa Milà.

Fishermen's tapas bar facing the port.

seo.h1_title: Costa Brava & Beyond: A Catalan Road Trip of Modernism, Coves & Bohemian Towns
seo.intro_paragraph: Barcelona and Gaudí, Girona and its medieval lanes, Tossa de Mar and its coves, the Dalí museum at Figueres. Catalonia blends architecture, beaches and culture.
seo.seo_hook: Modernist spires rise in organic curves, cove waters shimmer bright turquoise, pine forests scent the air. The Catalan coast is architecture come alive.

itineraries.title: Jaén's Renaissance Jewels: Olive Grove Landscapes & Wild Sierras of Andalusia

visits.text: Visit the Archaeological Museum of Linares, housed in the former 17th-century Casa del Torreón Palace. Discover a fascinating collection of artifacts from the Cástulo excavations, highlighting the famous Ibero-Roman sandstone lion originally from the northern wall of the ancient city.

Explore the Hospital of the Marquises of Linares, an impressive neo-Gothic building constructed between 1904 and 1917 commissioned by José de Murga and Raimunda de Osorio. Admire its Victorian architecture with gargoyles on the entrance columns and visit the Marquises' crypt with life-size sculptures.

Discover El Pósito, home to the Raphael Museum, one of the main cultural attractions in the singer's hometown. Admire his countless awards, records, and film costumes, including a very rare 1980 uranium disc that only artists like Michael Jackson or Queen have achieved.

Contemplate the Church of Santa María la Mayor, the oldest building in Linares constructed over a mosque in the 13th century. In Gothic-Renaissance style with participation from architect Andrés de Vandelvira, it was declared a basilica by Pope Francis in 2016.

activities.text: Stroll along the Paseo de Linarejos, a pleasant boulevard among green areas where locals enjoy tapas and gather. It begins at the white marble Constitution Fountain and culminates with the statue of guitarist Andrés Segovia, one of the city's most illustrious personalities.

Visit the Andrés Segovia House Museum in the 17th-century Orozco Palace. View the guitars that belonged to the maestro, his recognition medals, and the crypt where his remains rest. In November, it hosts the International Guitar Encounter.

visits.text: Explore the archaeological site of Cástulo, 5 kilometers from Linares, one of the most important Ibero-Roman settlements on the peninsula. This ancient city was the capital of Oretania and a strategic point in the wars between Rome and Carthage, with remains spanning from the Bronze Age to medieval times.

activities.text: Walk through the archaeological excavations where exceptional Roman mosaics, walls, necropolises, and public buildings have been discovered. The site continues to reveal treasures and offers a unique glimpse into life in ancient Hispania.

visits.text: Contemplate the Jabalquinto Palace, whose façade is one of the finest examples of Isabelline Gothic from the late 15th century. Now home to the International University of Andalusia, this palace impresses with its extraordinary sculptural decoration that rivals the best works of the Renaissance.

Visit the Cathedral of the Nativity of Our Lady, in 16th-century Renaissance style, which dominates the monumental landscape with its bell tower over 50 meters tall. Don't miss the 13th-century Gothic-Mudéjar Moon Gate with its lobed horseshoe arch and Gothic rose window.

Explore the Plaza de Santa María with the Santa María Fountain of 1564, built to celebrate the arrival of water to Baeza. In Renaissance style with a triumphal arch and coats of arms of the city and Philip II, it is one of the most beautiful fountains in Andalusia.

Discover the Plaza del Pópulo with the Fountain of the Lions, an archaeological monument whose sculptures come from the Roman city of Castulo. Crowned by Imilce, Iberian princess and wife of Carthaginian general Hannibal Barca, next to the Jaén Gate and the Villalar Arch.

activities.text: Visit the Old University where Antonio Machado taught French classes between 1912 and 1919. The classroom is preserved intact with the same period furniture and there is an exhibition dedicated to the Sevillian poet, whose presence is felt in many corners of the city.

Walk along the Paseo de las Murallas, the ancient route of the Almohad fortifications where remains of the Alcázar destroyed in 1476 by order of Isabella the Catholic are preserved. The views of the Guadalquivir valley dotted with olive groves as far as the eye can see are breathtaking.

Admire the Church of Santa Cruz facing the Jabalquinto Palace, one of the few Romanesque churches in Andalusia built in the 13th century. Its interior preserves frescoes from the early 16th century in the semicircular apse.

visits.text: Marvel at the Sacred Chapel of El Salvador, a masterpiece of Spanish Renaissance dated 1559. Created as the mausoleum of Francisco de los Cobos, secretary to Charles V, its façade is one of the most fascinating in Spain and represents the height of Renaissance art in Andalusia.

Explore Plaza Vázquez de Molina, the monumental heart of Úbeda where the most important Renaissance buildings are concentrated. Admire the Palacio de las Cadenas, built by Andrés de Vandelvira in 1562, and the Palacio del Deán Ortega, now a Parador Nacional hotel.

Visit the Collegiate Church of Santa María de los Reales Alcázares, built after the conquest by Ferdinand III the Saint in 1234 over the former main mosque. Its aesthetic value blends different styles from Gothic-Mudéjar to chapels from the 15th to 18th centuries, with Vandelvira's contribution.

Discover the Hospital de Santiago, considered one of Andrés de Vandelvira's finest works and the crowning achievement of Spanish Renaissance hospital architecture. Built between 1562 and 1575, its towers with glazed ceramic roofs and great central chapel stand out.

activities.text: Stroll through Plaza Primero de Mayo where you'll find the Old Town Hall with its arches on Corinthian columns and the Church of San Pablo, built over a mosque, whose southern portal is a rich example of Isabelline Gothic.

Explore the Vela de los Cobos Palace, another 16th-century Vandelvira masterpiece in perfect condition, with important furniture, library, historical archive, and collections of porcelain, ceramics, and coins. Also visit the Church of San Lorenzo built against the southern wall.

Walk along Calle Real, the main artery of the historic center with souvenir shops and restaurants, to Plaza de Andalucía presided over by the Clock Tower, from whose bell tower panoramic views of Úbeda and its surroundings can be enjoyed.

visits.text: Explore the town of Cazorla, the most important in the region at the foot of the sierra in the Cerezuelo River valley. This town combines heritage with landscape, crafts, and gastronomy, serving as the gateway to Spain's largest protected area.

Visit La Yedra Castle, a medieval fortress dominating the town, and discover the remains of Salvatierra Castle known as 'the one with five corners'. Cazorla's heritage includes Roman and Arab vestiges and constructions from the 14th to 17th centuries.

Discover La Iruela, a small white village at the foot of the sierra with a castle of Mozarabic origin highly coveted for centuries as it allowed spotting enemies from a great distance. Lose yourself in its steep, narrow alleyways full of legends.

activities.text: Visit Quesada, in whose municipal area the source of the Guadalquivir is located at Cañada de las Fuentes. Nearby is the Tíscar Water Cave, a natural monument with rock formations, drops, and waterfalls, next to La Peña Negra Castle.

visits.text: Contemplate the Tranco Reservoir, the heart of the Sierras de Cazorla, Segura y Las Villas Natural Park. One of Spain's largest reservoirs storing Guadalquivir waters, its calm waters are suitable for swimming, kayaking, canoeing, and electric boat rides.

Visit the source of the Guadalquivir River, Andalusia's main river that rises in the Sierra de Cazorla. After traveling a 12-kilometer track, you reach a quite peculiar spot—not the typical rock but a powerful springtime watercourse surrounded by nature and native wildlife.

Enjoy Charco de la Pringue, a natural pool in the Natural Park whose name comes from the legend of a donkey that fell in loaded with oil. The area is equipped with a swimming zone with clear Guadalquivir waters, recreational area, restaurant, and hiking trails.

activities.text: Take in the views from the Félix Rodríguez de la Fuente Viewpoint, named in honor of the documentary the famous naturalist filmed about bearded vultures on the island of Bujaraiza Castle. From Puerto de las Palomas Viewpoint at 1,200 meters, you can see the beginning of the Guadalquivir valley.

Hike the Borosa River and Cerrada de Elías route, one of the best hiking trails in the sierra. The 22-kilometer trail runs along wooden walkways beside the canyon to the Salto de los Órganos waterfall, Black Waters lagoon, and the source of the Borosa River.

Visit the Bearded Vulture Breeding Center in Nava de San Pedro, where work is being done to reintroduce this endangered bird that became extinct in Andalusia in 1986. Guides explain how the center operates and the breeding with minimal human intervention.

seo.h1_title: Jaén's Renaissance Jewels: Olive Grove Landscapes & Wild Sierras of Andalusia
seo.intro_paragraph: Discover the hidden treasures of Jaén province on this captivating 6-day journey through Spain's finest Renaissance architecture and most pristine natural landscapes. From the twin UNESCO World Heritage cities of Úbeda and Baeza to the breathtaking wilderness of the Cazorla Natural Park, this itinerary reveals an Andalusia far from the beaten path—where ancient Iberian ruins meet masterpieces by Vandelvira and endless seas of olive trees give way to crystalline mountain rivers.
seo.seo_hook: Where Renaissance palaces rise from seas of silver olive groves and wild mountain rivers carve through Spain's largest protected wilderness.
featured_list: Úbeda and Baeza: Twin UNESCO World Heritage Renaissance cities
Cástulo archaeological site: Ancient Ibero-Roman capital
Sierras de Cazorla Natural Park: Spain's largest protected area
Vandelvira's architectural masterpieces across Jaén province
Source of the Guadalquivir, Andalusia's great river
Endless olive groves and world-class olive oil

places_taglines.ES::linares: Mining heritage and birthplace of guitar legend Andrés Segovia
places_taglines.ES::castulo: Ancient Iberian capital where Rome and Carthage clashed
places_taglines.ES::baeza: Renaissance jewel where Machado wrote poetry among olive groves
places_taglines.ES::ubeda: Vandelvira's masterpiece city frozen in golden stone
places_taglines.ES::cazorla: Gateway to wild mountains where the Guadalquivir is born
places_taglines.ES::sierra-de-cazorla: Spain's largest protected wilderness of forests and crystal rivers

seo.h1_title: Navarre, Spain: Castles, Pyrenean Forests and the Camino de Santiago
seo.intro_paragraph: Pamplona on the Camino, Olite castle, Ujué village, Irati forest, Roncevaux pass. Navarra, land of pilgrims and legends.
seo.seo_hook: Castle turrets break through green forest, beech trees glow in the mist, pilgrim trails wind through mountain passes. Navarre is sacred ground.

seo.h1_title: Bay of Biscay Coastal Drive: Fishing Villages & Basque Culinary Soul in France
seo.intro_paragraph: Bilbao and the Guggenheim, Guernica and its memory, San Sebastián gastronomic capital, Getaria fishing village. Spanish Basque Country, proud and gourmet.
seo.seo_hook: Fishing boats dance on turquoise waters, pintxos gleam golden and crisp, mountains break through the mist. The Basque coast has a soul all its own.

seo.intro_paragraph: Huelva, Punta Umbría and El Rompido beaches, Jabugo ham, Aracena caves, Riotinto mines, El Rocío and its pilgrimage. Huelva province, between Atlantic and Sierra Morena.
seo.seo_hook: Mine tunnels echo copper light, beaches stretch along the Atlantic, jamón aroma rises from wood fires. Huelva is living heritage.

seo.h1_title: Ibiza and Formentera Guide: Beyond the Clubs to Turquoise Coves and Beaches
seo.intro_paragraph: Playa d'en Bossa, Las Salinas, Cala Comte for sunset in Ibiza, then Espalmador and Ses Illetes in Formentera. From party beaches to deserted coves.
seo.seo_hook: Turquoise waters shimmer almost unreal, golden sands stretch forever, pine forests scent the air. Ibiza is beach paradise.

itineraries.title: León's Mountain Villages: Las Médulas, Riaño & The Camino de Santiago

visits.text: Village of Balboa and its traditional Celtic-style pallozas
Church of Santa María de Balboa, blend of styles from the 13th to 16th century

activities.text: Walk in the Sierra de los Ancares around Balboa

visits.text: Discovery of the village of Villafranca del Bierzo, major stop on the Camino de Santiago
Visit to the collegiate church Santa María de Cluniaco

activities.text: Walk through the historic center of Villafranca del Bierzo

visits.text: Medieval village of Molinaseca, stone houses and listed historic center
Roman bridge of Molinaseca over the Meruelo river
Church of San Nicolás de Bari

activities.text: Stroll through the medieval streets of Molinaseca

visits.text: Village of Peñalba de Santiago, stone and wood architecture in the heart of the Oza valley
Church of Santiago, built in the 10th century

activities.text: Panoramic walk in the Oza valley around Peñalba

visits.text: Visit to the village of Lombillo de los Barrios
San Martín Church
Bierzo viewpoint

activities.text: Walk through the historic districts of Lombillo and Salas de los Barrios

visits.text: City of Astorga, stop on the Camino de Compostela and rich historical heritage
Cathedral of Santa María of Astorga, Gothic style
Episcopal Palace of Astorga, work by Gaudí

activities.text: Walk through the historic center of Astorga

visits.text: Village of Castrillo de los Polvazares, medieval alleys and ochre stone houses

activities.text: Stroll through the historic streets of Castrillo de los Polvazares

visits.text: Santa Colomba de Somoza and its traditional maragato buildings
Parish church of the Asunción

activities.text: Walk in the traditional Maragatería

visits.text: Historic village of Sahagún, witness to the passage of numerous cultures
San Tirso Church, 12th-century Romanesque-Mudéjar example
Royal monastery San Benito

activities.text: Walk through the medieval center of Sahagún

visits.text: Village of Arbas del Puerto, located at the Pajares pass
Collegiate Church of Santa María de Arbas

activities.text: Walk through the mountainous landscapes around the Pajares pass

visits.text: Ancestral village of Balouta, traditional pallozas and natural setting of the Ancares

activities.text: Discovery of the Ancares valley around Balouta

seo.h1_title: León's Mountain Villages: Las Médulas, Riaño & The Camino de Santiago
seo.intro_paragraph: Villafranca del Bierzo on the Camino, Molinaseca, Peñalba monastery, Astorga and Gaudí's palace. Mountain villages of León province.
seo.seo_hook: Stone villages glow mountain gray, monastery bells ring through the valleys, pilgrim paths wind toward the sacred. León is heritage.

itineraries.title: Sierra de Francia, Spain: Medieval Stone Villages and Mountain Landscapes

visits.text: Village of Sequeros and typical architecture
Monastery of Peña de Francia (Sequeros)
Sanctuary of Nuestra Señora del Robledo (Sequeros)
Village of Montemayor del Río and oak forest
San Vicente Castle (Montemayor del Río)
Painted facades of Mogarraz
Main square of La Alberca
San Marcos Church (La Alberca)
Nuestra Señora de la Asunción Church (La Alberca)
Puente del Arroyo (La Alberca)
Village of Miranda del Castañar and its castle
Cristo del Humilladero Church (Miranda del Castañar)
Virgen de la Cuesta Church (Miranda del Castañar)
Torre de las Campanas (Miranda del Castañar)
Medieval bridge and Tormes river at Puente del Congosto
Dávila family castle (Puente del Congosto)
Village of Alba de Tormes and Saint Teresa pilgrimage
Basilica of Saint Teresa (Alba de Tormes)
Monastery of the Annunciation (Alba de Tormes)
Castle of Alba (Alba de Tormes)
Gate and wall of Monleón
Town of Ledesma, bridge over the Tormes river
Castle of Ledesma
Casa de las Almenas (Ledesma)
Village of San Felices de los Gallegos and its medieval castle
Bridge of the French (San Felices de los Gallegos)
Arribes del Duero Natural Park (San Felices de los Gallegos)

seo.h1_title: Sierra de Francia, Spain: Medieval Stone Villages and Mountain Landscapes
seo.intro_paragraph: La Alberca with portraits on facades, Mogarraz, Miranda del Castañar, Ledesma. Sierra de Francia, medieval villages preserved in Salamanca's mountains.
seo.seo_hook: Medieval stone glows mountain gray, ramparts rise as tall sentinels, coats of arms proudly grace the facades. The Sierra is medieval.

itineraries.title: Valencia's Art & Paella: City of Arts & Sciences & Albufera Wetlands
itineraries.notes: Une Méditerranée lumineuse entre lagunes, palmeraies UNESCO et cités portuaires.

visits.text: City of Arts and Sciences — Calatrava's futuristic complex.
Central Market — dome and colorful stalls.
Old town — cathedral, Miguelete and silk exchange (Lonja, UNESCO).

activities.text: Bike ride in Turia park.
Traditional Valencian paella at noon.
Horchata and fartons aperitif at the Oceanogràfic.

visits.text: Boats on the lagoon at sunset.
Rice fields and bird observatories.
Village of El Palmar — traditional barraca houses.

activities.text: Paella cooking class over wood fire.
Morning bird watching.
All i pebre tasting in local tavern.

visits.text: Castle of Xàtiva — two fortresses on the ridge.
Old town — Via palace and collegiate church.
Fountain of 25 spouts — local symbol.

activities.text: Short hike to the castle viewpoints.
Tasting of dacsa shells.
Valencian ceramics workshop.

visits.text: Santa Bárbara Castle — views over the bay.
Esplanade of Spain — undulating mosaics.
Santa Cruz Quarter — flowered alleyways.

activities.text: Swimming and paddleboarding on Postiguet beach.
Funicular to the castle then sunset.
Evening seafood tapas at the port.

visits.text: Palm Grove of Elche — UNESCO-listed urban oasis.
Basilica of Santa María and Misteri d'Elx.
Huerto del Cura — historic garden.

activities.text: Palm weaving workshop.
Tasting of local dates.
Shaded walk in the huertos.

seo.h1_title: Valencia's Art & Paella: City of Arts & Sciences & Albufera Wetlands
seo.intro_paragraph: Valencia between Art Nouveau and City of Arts and Sciences, Albufera rice fields, Xàtiva castles, Alicante beaches and Elche palm groves. The Valencia region surprises.
seo.seo_hook: Art Nouveau curves gleam gold, rice paddies mirror blue skies, paella aromas rise. Valencia is modern heritage.
